div.p:
Moses gives you many thanks for your remittance & incloses the receit. I am putting in the first leaves of the
welsh tour the arms of my alliances or in fact my pedegree.Arms of families are painted in the margins of text relating to Tre-Mostyn (pp. 8, 9) and Tre-Bychton (p. 14) in NLW, Pennant's extra-illustrated Tour in Wales (1st edn., 1778), SEVEN. I presume that will not interest you, so shall omit it.i.e. in Bull's copy.

I fear Lord Herberts house at Eyton Edward Herbert, first Baron Herbert of Cherbury and first Baron Herbert of Castle Island (1582?–1648). He was born at Eyton-on-Severn, Shropshire, home of his maternal grandparents, Sir Richard (d.1570) and Lady Margaret Newport. ODNB. A building at Eyton, dated c.1607 and described as a banqueting house, is said to have been destroyed by fire. It is linked to the name of Sir Francis Newport. See historicengland.org.uk, list entry no. 1267039 [accessed 9/12/17]. Whether this was the same as the house at Eyton-on-Severn rebuilt by 1595 by Sir Francis Newport (c.1555–1623), of High Ercall and Eyton-on-Severn, is unclear. ODNB s.v. Richard Newport, first Baron Newport (1587–1651); History of Parliament on-line s.v. Francis Newport II (c.1555–1623). is burnt down: but I shall make enquiry The tomb in Montgomery Ch. Church
is of Richard Herbert Esqr
Esquire
& his wife.A tour in Wales MDCCLXX, II, part 2, ii [ECCO describes as vol. 2; actually part of 'From Downing to Montgomery and Shrewsbury'], p. 374, describes a 'handsome monument of Richard Herbert, Esq; . . . represented in armour; and by him lies his lady, Magdalene, daughter of Sir Richard Newport of High Arcol. In front are their numerous progeny. He died in 1597. The monument was erected by his lady, who survived him several years . . .'. he in armr
armour beneath a marble canopy – beneath the tomb is another figure of a man in a gown with a cord round his waste. his head hooded Two mutilated figures of Knights. the head of one rests on a helmet with a coronet & vast plumes. If you can give me any history of them I shall be much obliged to you for it will be of immediate use to

postscript.p: Be so good as to try to get explained the words in old writing in the list of Sir J. Wynn's wardrobe,WORDS IN OLD WRITING IN THE LIST OF SIR J. WYNN'S WARDROBE & return me the paper.
